description: The Melbourne spring carnival program will remain unchanged after the Racing Victoria board unanimously voted against a reshuffle of race dates on Friday.
text:
Caulfield chief slams Racing Victoria for 'gutless' call on carnival Melbourne
Racing Club chairman Peter Le Grand has slammed Racing Victoria and accused
its board of being "gutless", "weak" and reluctant to take any risks after the
sporting body knocked back a proposal to radically change the spring carnival.
Le Grand unleashed a barrage of criticism at RV's administrators, saying they
lacked imagination for refusing to countenance a revolutionary revamp of the
traditional carnival dates. However, the club's chief executive, Josh
Blanksby, has vowed to try again next year, believing racing has an
opportunity to own vacant sporting calendar space in late November. Le Grand
did not hold back in a radio interview aired just minutes after RV chairman
Brian Kruger announced via the industry-owned [racing.com](http://racing.com)
that his board had voted unanimously to "effectively leave the dates as they
have been traditionally". The MRC was proposing to move its Caulfield Cup and
Guineas features to the back end of November to avoid a clash with AFL finals
and to give its members a greater chance of attending the races. "Another weak
decision, totally predictable, gutless position as far as I'm concerned," Le
Grand said on SEN. "Here was an opportunity to be different in racing, to be
innovative and try something different. There's absolutely no innovation
coming out of RVL. "Fair dinkum, I'm nearly speechless. I can't believe it.
Here was an opportunity in COVID-19 times to put it back a month, give people
and members a chance to get the races in better weather, and what do we do?
Just keep on going the way you're going, don't change anything, just go along
with what we've been doing the last hundred years." Kruger said RV had
undergone a six-week process "at least" to explore how a revamped program
might have looked, in order to avoid a clash with AFL finals and give the
sport a better chance at hosting crowds. However, he said any potential upside
to overhauling its time-honoured carnival were uncertain enough "to warrant
making such a significant change". "The spring racing carnival has been so
successful, it really is a global icon and we felt in order to consider making
changes, even in this COVID-effected world, there really needed to be some
compelling reasons for us to do that," Kruger said. Blanksby said the MRC
would "absolutely" look at the proposal for next year's spring. "We put this
up because we feel that's a period of the sporting calendar that's vacant," he
said. "There's better weather and racing can have that chance to absolutely
own that space. It's been a really positive debate, the pros and cons, so
we'll monitor how [wagering] results go this spring … and then see how it
goes." Blanksby added he would ask RV for its wagering analysis after Kruger
said bookmakers were split on whether a November spring carnival would
materially improve the sport's wagering income. The Victoria Racing Club has
been adamant the Melbourne Cup carnival and its traditional first Tuesday in
November date is sacrosanct and would not be moving. Moonee Valley Racing Club
had opted to stay in its traditional late October space too, with every
likelihood that the Cox Plate will now be an afternoon hors d'oeuvres for a
night AFL grand final on October 24. VRC chief executive Neil Wilson said it
was "good to have clarity". "We were not opposed to it [running the Caulfield
Cup later in the year] but we know the programme as is, is a model that
works," he said. Moonee Valley boss Michael Browell said: "the club was
willing to consider both options. We now retain the two-day carnival, Friday
night with the Manikato as the headline and the 100th running of the Cox Plate
on the Saturday. "We are happy to retain the traditional carnival format but
were equally as happy to consider the one-off change this year, to accommodate
the MRC's request in light of the impact of COVID." RV has, however, decided
to move the Underwood Stakes - which is traditionally held on the Sunday after
the AFL grand final - back to a Saturday meeting, while confirming the
preferred race time for the October 24 Cox Plate was during the day.

title: Caulfield chief slams Racing Victoria for 'gutless' call on carnival [Brisbane Times (Australia)]
html: Caulfield chief slams Racing Victoria for 'gutless' call on carnival Melbourne Racing Club chairman Peter Le Grand has slammed Racing Victoria and accused its board of being "gutless", "weak" and reluctant to take any risks after the sporting body knocked back a proposal to radically change the spring carnival. Le Grand unleashed a barrage of criticism at RV's administrators, saying they lacked imagination for refusing to countenance a revolutionary revamp of the traditional carnival dates. However, the club's chief executive, Josh Blanksby, has vowed to try again next year, believing racing has an opportunity to own vacant sporting calendar space in late November. Le Grand did not hold back in a radio interview aired just minutes after RV chairman Brian Kruger announced via the industry-owned racing.com that his board had voted unanimously to "effectively leave the dates as they have been traditionally". The MRC was proposing to move its Caulfield Cup and Guineas features to the back end of November to avoid a clash with AFL finals and to give its members a greater chance of attending the races. "Another weak decision, totally predictable, gutless position as far as I'm concerned," Le Grand said on SEN. "Here was an opportunity to be different in racing, to be innovative and try something different. There's absolutely no innovation coming out of RVL. "Fair dinkum, I'm nearly speechless. I can't believe it. Here was an opportunity in COVID-19 times to put it back a month, give people and members a chance to get the races in better weather, and what do we do? Just keep on going the way you're going, don't change anything, just go along with what we've been doing the last hundred years." Kruger said RV had undergone a six-week process "at least" to explore how a revamped program might have looked, in order to avoid a clash with AFL finals and give the sport a better chance at hosting crowds. However, he said any potential upside to overhauling its time-honoured carnival were uncertain enough "to warrant making such a significant change". "The spring racing carnival has been so successful, it really is a global icon and we felt in order to consider making changes, even in this COVID-effected world, there really needed to be some compelling reasons for us to do that," Kruger said. Blanksby said the MRC would "absolutely" look at the proposal for next year's spring. "We put this up because we feel that's a period of the sporting calendar that's vacant," he said. "There's better weather and racing can have that chance to absolutely own that space. It's been a really positive debate, the pros and cons, so we'll monitor how [wagering] results go this spring … and then see how it goes." Blanksby added he would ask RV for its wagering analysis after Kruger said bookmakers were split on whether a November spring carnival would materially improve the sport's wagering income. The Victoria Racing Club has been adamant the Melbourne Cup carnival and its traditional first Tuesday in November date is sacrosanct and would not be moving. Moonee Valley Racing Club had opted to stay in its traditional late October space too, with every likelihood that the Cox Plate will now be an afternoon hors d'oeuvres for a night AFL grand final on October 24. VRC chief executive Neil Wilson said it was "good to have clarity". "We were not opposed to it [running the Caulfield Cup later in the year] but we know the programme as is, is a model that works," he said. Moonee Valley boss Michael Browell said: "the club was willing to consider both options. We now retain the two-day carnival, Friday night with the Manikato as the headline and the 100th running of the Cox Plate on the Saturday. "We are happy to retain the traditional carnival format but were equally as happy to consider the one-off change this year, to accommodate the MRC's request in light of the impact of COVID." RV has, however, decided to move the Underwood Stakes - which is traditionally held on the Sunday after the AFL grand final - back to a Saturday meeting, while confirming the preferred race time for the October 24 Cox Plate was during the day.
